title: Hong Kong withdraws extradition bill, protests go on
text:
Hong Kong's government moved Wednesday to withdraw a bill that sparked months of protests in the city, handing a major victory to demonstrators who showed no signs of abandoning the streets after the news.

The Associated Press and Reuters reported that lawmakers officially withdrew a bill Wednesday that would have allowed Chinese authorities to extradite Hong Kong citizens to the mainland to face criminal charges for certain crimes.

ADVERTISEMENT

The bill was widely criticized as an assault on the province's autonomy and led to months of massive pro-democracy protests in the streets of Hong Kong, which continue to this day despite the extradition plan's suspension weeks ago.

“There aren’t any big differences between suspension and withdrawal [of the extradition bill]... It’s too little, too late,” one 27-year-old protester told Reuters. “There are still other demands the government needs to meet, especially the problem of police brutality.”

Hong Kong and China's government have repeatedly urged demonstrators to return to their homes and abandon the protests, a suggestion that has had little success over the past few months in the face of anger over issues such as police violence and treatment of demonstrators.

The controversy has made its way to the U.S. as well, with the NBA currently being embroiled in a scandal over pro-Hong Kong comments by Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey, who enraged the Chinese government and some Chinese citizens with a tweet in support of the protesters.
description: Hong Kong's government moved Wednesday to withdraw a bill that sparked months of protests in the city, handing a major victory to demonstrators who showed no signs of abandoning the streets after the news.
